summary.p: Returned to Konstanz on August 26; was dismissed by Duke Ulrich of W端rttemberg with grace, but with shabby payment, and asks Bullinger to counter rumors that he was sent away in anger; hopes for a later, more generous compensation from the Duke. Greetings.

div.p: Greetings, my venerable and excellent Bullinger.

I recently returned to Konstanz, that is, on August 26, with the good grace of the Duke of W端rttemberg, except that he paid me less generously than was fair; for I suffered a loss of almost 300 gold coins during the entire four years, in which I was overwhelmed and utterly exhausted by the unbearable labors in his domain. And yet I thank my God that, having been released from there with a good conscience, I am now restored to my own. However, I wanted to inform you of this in a few words, although I am very busy, so that I know what rumors my friends might spread, namely that I was sent away by an angry prince, so that you have something to counter them with; for whatever the prince did wrong here, he did it not out of anger, but out of habit. For that is his way. However, I hope that someday, through some favorable opportunity, he will kindly compensate what I now desire and exercise a generosity worthy of a prince, since he is otherwise not ill-disposed towards me.

Commend me to the most illustrious men Pellican, Leo, Theodor, and the other brothers and friends, whose prayers, along with yours, I earnestly wish to be aided by before Christ. The people of Z端rich greet you, along with my brother and sister. Farewell, my more than dearest and best brother.
In Konstanz, the last day of August, 1538.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, Bishop of the Church of Z端rich, my lord and most esteemed brother, etc.
